author: cskiraly
content: Who is doing this dashboard, and how is "dial success" measured here?

author: barnabasbusa
content: do we have a final version of 7910? We would like to add support for it in dora for specific fields, but looks like there was still some discussions about it last week.

author: mariohavel
content:
It's an open source crawler run by <@243445974461186048> https://github.com/ethereum/node-crawler

Dial success means whether the crawler successfully connected to the peer. It continuously tries to connect to peers and dial fails if the node is unreachable via public or refuses for too many peers. Check the list of nodes and individual discovered nodes for details, each has a report of previous dial in/out attempts with errors https://www.ethernets.io/nodes/

author: angaz
content:
It's still a success if it's got too many peers. Too many peers means I was able to connect to the node and I know it's at least an ETH node because the handshake was successful.
Dial failure is only if I am not able to connect to the node, like connection timeout, connection refused, or the IP is unroutable.
It's a good point that it should be explained.

author: _shemnon
content: I don't anticipate further changes to eth_config/7910 for Fusaka. The changes are in and covered all the issues discussed last week.

author: marekm3498
content:
I believe our recent fixes to Nethermind should improve the situation. One fix addresses the connection between Geth and Nethermind, and another corrects an issue where we were incorrectly sending the "too many peers" error, causing such nodes to be not found by the crawler.

Once people upgrade to the latest Nethermind version, we should start seeing more Nethermind nodes in the crawler.

<@243445974461186048>, is it possible to get some aggregated data? For example, can we see that X number of Nethermind nodes responded with "too many peers" or sth else
